Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of pulsed floral resources on pollinator population dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will explore how one result of landscape change, the timing and availability of flowers, affects populations of bumble bees, a prominent group of native bees that pollinate many crops and wildflowers in North America. Bumble bees are important because more than one-third of the food we eat comes from crops that depend to some degree on the type of pollination they provide. Although non-native honey bees remain a cornerstone of agricultural pollination, native bees are increasingly the focus of agricultural attention in light of ongoing challenges facing honey bees. Healthy populations of native bees rely on continuous supplies of pollen and nectar. However, the availability of these floral resources has been dramatically altered by unpredictable weather associated with changing climate, and by human activities, including intensive agriculture. The investigators will study how changes in the timing and availability of flowers affect the number of bumble bees. This research is a significant advance over past studies, which used patterns of bee visits to flowers to make broad conclusions about the overall health of bee populations and communities. In contrast, the current study will focus on reproductive success of bee hives. The results will be key to developing strategies to promote robust populations of bees and ensure food security, as well as to conserve biological diversity.

Specifically, the project combines manipulative field experiments and original demographic population models to assess effects of within-year resource variation (resource pulses) on population dynamics of bumble bees. The experiments will be conducted with Bombus vosnesenskii, a dominant bumble bee species in Northern California. Investigators will conduct experiments in which flower availability and timing are systematically altered. They will then measure how vital rates of individual colonies (e.g., worker production, worker survival, and queen production) depend on the availability of floral resources at different times in the colony life cycle. To ensure a consistent baseline of hive quality, all measurements will be made on lab-reared colonies started from wild-collected queens. Experimental results will be combined with demographic models to predict long-term population viability of bees under different landscape conditions. This research will answer questions about how ongoing landscape change will affect Bombus vosnesenskii and other bee species. It also will provide a previously-missing framework for population viability analysis of bees and other social insects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bumble bees are among the most important pollinators of both crop plants and wildflowers.  Unfortunately, many species of bumble bees are in decline worldwide.  Although we know a lot about how bumble bees forage for pollen and nectar, we know much less about their biology throughout their life cycle.  Bumble bees have social colonies like honey bees, but, unlike honey bees, these colonies last for only one summer.  At the end of the summer, colonies switch from producing worker bees to producing new queens and male bees.  By fall, only the new queens are still alive.  These new queens hibernate for the winter, emerge in spring, search for new nesting sites, and establish new colonies by early summer.  In other words, although most of what we know about bees comes from worker bees foraging during summer, most of the annual life cycle is spent by solitary queen bumble bees.

 

With this grant, we tested how the availability of forage resources affected the growth of bumble bee (Bombus vosnesneskii) colonies through time within a single year.  This research was done in the Central Valley of California, in collaboration with Prof. Neal Williams and Dr. Rosemary Malfi at UC Davis.  In the Central Valley, native plants flower mostly early in spring, before the dry summer.  Irrigated agricultural crops have peak flowering later in summer.  Therefore, although natural and agricultural landscapes have the same amount of flowers overall, they produce flowers at different times during bumble bee colony growth.  We used experiments to test how the timing of resources affected bumble bee colony growth.  We found that early season growth was disproportionately important.  (This result is similar to the way that early childhood nutrition affects human health later in life.)  Bumble bee workers in higher-resource environments were larger, and larger bees are better at foraging for more resources, leading to increased ability to get new resources even after the pulse ended. 

 

We also used part of this grant to study parts of the life cycle when queens are solitary.  This research was done in Massachusetts, on farms owned by a local land trust (The Trustees of Reservations.  We tracked movement of bumble bee (Bombus impatiens) queens in spring, and found the sites where they established their nests in the ground.  We learned B. impatiens nest in natural meadows and forests, but not grazed hay fields.  We monitored growth of these colonies throughout the summer, and queen production at the end of the summer.  We learned that colonies nesting in forests near meadow edges produced more new queens than colonies in the meadows.  In other words, although most flower resources are in meadows, the better nest sites may be in forests near meadows.  We found sites where bumble bee queens hibernated during winter, which were often surprisingly close to the nests where they were born.  We discovered that most queens survived the winter.  At sites where queens could burrow deeper in the soil more than 75% survived the winter, but at a site with shallow soil, just under half the bees survived the winter.  These are the first data of their kind measured for bumble bees in the wild.

 

Our experimental results are especially exciting because they confirm theories about how changes in the body size of animals can have long-lasting effects on populations.  These theories were developed by scientists thinking about vertebrate animals and long-lived plants, so it is exciting that they can also be used to understand how bumble bee colonies grow.  Our field monitoring is especially exciting because lack of knowledge about the full life cycle of bumble bees has limited effective conservation.  Our success in monitoring bumble bees is an example for research on bumble bees throughout the world.  For example, the US Fish and Wildlife Service recently recognized lack of knowledge of nesting and hibernation habitat as a major factor limiting conservation of the rusty patched bumble bee (Bombus affinis), an endangered species.  We will be working with USFWS staff and local biologists during the summer of 2021 to teach them the methods we developed as part of this project.

 

In addition to research, this grant provided partial funding for two Ph.D. students, Natalie Kerr and Genevieve Pugesek, and one postdoctoral research scholar, David Iles, at Tufts University.  Dr. Kerr led the part of our project linking bumble bee body size to future colony growth, and is now a postdoctoral scholar at Duke University.  Ms. Pugesek will be defending her Ph.D. in spring 2021, and leading our technology transfer project with rusty patched bumble bees.  Dr. Iles is now a Wildlife Biologist with the Canadian Wildlife Service.  This grant also provided training opportunities for several undergraduate students and helped provide the momentum on campus for forming the student-led Tufts Pollinator Initiative (https://sites.tufts.edu/pollinators/).
